title: PHOTOS: Stars come out as the Venice Architecture Biennale opens
author: Josh Niland
excerpt: The 2025 Venice Architecture Biennale has all the looks of a must-see event as we celebrate its official opening this weekend in the Giardini, Arsenale, and other satellite locations spread across the floating city. Social media posts streaming in from the six-month fair capture the excitement and...
text: The 2025 Venice Architecture Biennale has all the looks of a must-see event as we celebrate its official opening this weekend in the Giardini, Arsenale, and other satellite locations spread across the floating city. Social media posts streaming in from the six-month fair capture the excitement and community on the ground for the 19th International Architecture Exhibition, where curatorial teams and their audiences expound on its theme 'Intelligens. Natural. Artificial. Collective.’ This is an opportunity to see the experiments growing out of the living laboratories of each individual national pavilion as they come together in convocation to chart a new course for practitioners of the built environment worldwide. Curator Carlo Ratti talked about this and how he views the event as an urgent and to reflect on. (As he told us this week in an exclusive interview, "architecture is about survival.")  In all, over 750 participants are attending. The best shots from the opening week are included in our roundup sampler below.  Image courtesy @crassociati/InstagramAs you would expect, Ratti's Instagram has some cool behind-the-scenes shots of panel discussions featuring an interdisciplinary selection of invitees—engineers, computer scientists, mathematicians, and others—whose variety itself reflects his long-held research interests.  Image courtesy @porchusa2025/InstagramJeanne Gang, Kate Orff, TEN x TEN, and some of the total cohort invited to exhibit in the U.S. Pavilion's PORCH presentation have some great insiders' views to follow up on our own preview from earlier this week. Inside the PORCH, our friends from Los Angeles-based FORT: LA captured some laid-back swingin' vibes. (Find more exclusive photos they took for Archinect in the image gallery below!) Studio Gang has more details on its inclusion in the Biennale Image courtesy @rojkind/InstagramMichel Rojkind gave us a close-up look at his friend Bjarke Ingels and a group of Bhutanese woodworkers showing off their craft side-by-side with CNC robots. (BIG is working on a master plan called Gelephu Mindfulness City that lends from the local craft tradition there for 2029.)  Critic Oliver Wainwright made it on time for this year's fair (his review of which can be read here) and has already found some of the best 3D printing and robotic fabrication examples the Biennale has to offer.  MAD Architects principal Qun Dang has some shots of the Chinese Pavilion, which is curated by Ma Yansong and hosts an exhibition focusing on "how tradition and technology can move together quietly, thoughtfully, and with care." Image courtesy @mayansong_mad/InstagramYansong has shared some extra images from inside the Chinese Pavilion via his stories. Image courtesy @mayansong_mad/InstagramLina Ghotmeh shared a shot of a morning panel discussion she was part of with Carlo Ratti, Sou Fujimoto, Sumayya Vally, and Hans Ulrich Obrist. Check out designer Mihai Gurei's pics from inside the Romanian Pavilion, where an exhibition about using the human scale to model space in architectural drawing. SCI-Arc's newly named Director/CEO, Winka Dubbeldam, is in Venice checking out the Albanian Pavilion.  Placemaking and cultural sector strategist Lucy Bullivant photos show some of the sights, scenes, style, and exhibitions from around Venice. Journalist Sandra Hoffmeister has a look at the Holy See's exhibition timed (unintentionally) with the announcement of the new Pope Leo XIV on Thursday. Sydney-based architect Adam Haddow takes us inside the Australian Pavilion, which is hosting an exhibition focused on the notion of home grounded by a special First Nations-led design and interactive experience.
html:
The 2025 Venice Architecture Biennale has all the looks of a must-see event as we celebrate its official opening this weekend in the Giardini, Arsenale, and other satellite locations spread across the floating city.

Social media posts streaming in from the six-month fair capture the excitement and community on the ground for the 19th International Architecture Exhibition, where curatorial teams and their audiences expound on its theme 'Intelligens. Natural. Artificial. Collective.’

This is an opportunity to see the experiments growing out of the living laboratories of each individual national pavilion as they come together in convocation to chart a new course for practitioners of the built environment worldwide. Curator Carlo Ratti talked about this and how he views the event as an urgent and to reflect on. (As he told us this week in an exclusive interview, "architecture is about survival.") 

In all, over 750 participants are attending. The best shots from the opening week are included in our roundup sampler below. 

As you would expect, Ratti's Instagram has some cool behind-the-scenes shots of panel discussions featuring an interdisciplinary selection of invitees—engineers, computer scientists, mathematicians, and others—whose variety itself reflects his long-held research interests. 

Jeanne Gang, Kate Orff, TEN x TEN, and some of the total cohort invited to exhibit in the U.S. Pavilion's PORCH presentation have some great insiders' views to follow up on our own preview from earlier this week.


Inside the PORCH, our friends from Los Angeles-based FORT: LA captured some laid-back swingin' vibes. (Find more exclusive photos they took for Archinect in the image gallery below!)

Studio Gang has more details on its inclusion in the Biennale

Michel Rojkind gave us a close-up look at his friend Bjarke Ingels and a group of Bhutanese woodworkers showing off their craft side-by-side with CNC robots. (BIG is working on a master plan called Gelephu Mindfulness City that lends from the local craft tradition there for 2029.) 

Critic Oliver Wainwright made it on time for this year's fair (his review of which can be read here) and has already found some of the best 3D printing and robotic fabrication examples the Biennale has to offer. 

MAD Architects principal Qun Dang has some shots of the Chinese Pavilion, which is curated by Ma Yansong and hosts an exhibition focusing on "how tradition and technology can move together quietly, thoughtfully, and with care."

Yansong has shared some extra images from inside the Chinese Pavilion via his stories.

Lina Ghotmeh shared a shot of a morning panel discussion she was part of with Carlo Ratti, Sou Fujimoto, Sumayya Vally, and Hans Ulrich Obrist.

Check out designer Mihai Gurei's pics from inside the Romanian Pavilion, where an exhibition about using the human scale to model space in architectural drawing.

SCI-Arc's newly named Director/CEO, Winka Dubbeldam, is in Venice checking out the Albanian Pavilion. 

Placemaking and cultural sector strategist Lucy Bullivant photos show some of the sights, scenes, style, and exhibitions from around Venice.

Journalist Sandra Hoffmeister has a look at the Holy See's exhibition timed (unintentionally) with the announcement of the new Pope Leo XIV on Thursday.

Sydney-based architect Adam Haddow takes us inside the Australian Pavilion, which is hosting an exhibition focused on the notion of home grounded by a special First Nations-led design and interactive experience.
